questions.text: The team decides the size of the next sprint independently and without pressure.
All team members have a common understanding of the work.
Each member of the team contributes appropriately to Sprint Planning.
Tickets are only added to the sprint when they meet the Definition Of Ready
All members of the team agree on the planned work and sprint goal.
Takes place at the end of a sprint and immediately before starting the next one.
The volume of work taken into sprint is based on the story points.
The total number of points in the sprint feels acheivable

Daily stand-ups are a quick check-in, taking under 10 mins.
If the PO is present, they are there in an observational capacity – but can be called on to give input.
The Sprint Goals the team have set are a focus and referred to / encouraged.
Everyone in the team knows who is currently working on what – and has a high-level understanding of what the topic is.
The team feel confident to highlight any blocking issues for the day.
Significant impediments are handled by the Scrum Master outside of the meeting.
The stand-up is at the same time each day.
The stand-up can be run independently of the scrum master.

Extensive customer/PO feedback is an integral part of each of the sprint cycles.
The last Sprint Reviews have created a good basis for the preparation of the following Sprints.
The team ensure that all relevant stakeholders can participate regularly enough in our Sprint Reviews.
The Sprint Review happens every Sprint, at the end of every sprint, before the retro and sprint planning.
The Sprint Review is recorded/documented on Confluence
The Sprint Review focuses on working software.
Stakeholders are well briefed on the agenda.
The Sprint Review is seen in a performance context against other sprints.

The effort and time that the team spends at these meetings are well-invested.
The retrospectives are documented and can be referred back.
Members can freely express opinions and suggest ideas, share opinions, etc. without them being talked down or over immediately.
Opinions and feedback are factual, not personal.
The team identify how they want to improve – and demonstrates that happening in the next sprint.
Both good and bad experiences are shared about the previous sprint – these can be a mix of technical and personal too.
Strong voices are encouraged but managed.
Quieter voices are encouraged and amplified.
Sprint Retrospective happens every Sprint, at the end of the sprint, and before the sprint planning.
Can happen independently of the PO or Scrum Master being present.
The PO attends the stand-up in an observational capacity and contributes when asked.
The PO is engaged in Sprint Reviews.
The PO is available to the Scrum Master when needed.
The PO works with the Scrum Master to keep a healthy backlog.
The PO is writing and preparing tickets that comply with the definition of ready (to start).
The team has a single PO.
The PO does not tell the dev team how to estimate or implement the work itself.
The PO prioritises what working software needs to be delivered in the following sprint.

The performance of our team is stable and plannable over several sprints.
The Scrum Master is engaged and interested in the process of managing the work cycle.
The Scrum Master shields the team from the PO where needed.
The Scrum Master leads the stand-up and other ceremonies.
The Scrum Master works with the PO to comb the backlog regularly.
The Scrum Master plans the next sprint in advance of it starting.
The Scrum Master works to ensure that tickets meet the definition of ready.
The Scrum Master (with the PO) moves tickets to Done only when the definition of done is reached.

Team members, Product Owner and Scrum Master share the same understanding of their respective roles in the team.
The team share unfinished work with stakeholders early to get feedback as quickly as possible.
If a team member makes a mistake, they are not judged for it.
The team is good at making decisions.
There are plenty of opportunities for informal exchange with colleagues.
There is a constructive exchange of knowledge happening between newer and more experienced colleagues.
The team maintain a close exchange with other teams, customers and service providers in order to be innovative.
The team frequently mob and pair throughout the sprint to get tickets to Done.
The team as a charter - a written set of values they live by.
Team completes work to Definition of Done
Backlog refinement in the team is efficient and effective.
Backlog refinement in the team happens each sprint.
There are at least two sprint’s worth of tickets ready in the Product Backlog.
The team make time in each sprint to size the top x number of tickets.
The product backlog is well-maintained and ordered.
Are tickets small enough?
Are tickets independent?

The definition of done is satisfied before a ticket is moved to Done.
If a ticket is brought into the sprint a ticket of the same or more value is removed.
The team are responsible for delivering a ticket, not just an assigned person.
